did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Cayuga Lodge papers, 1937-1997.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Include materials documenting the history of this men's cooperative residence (now co-ed, formerly Llenroc Lodge and Cayuga Student Resident Association)

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Include house minutes of this men's cooperative residence (now co-ed, formerly Llenroc Lodge and Cayuga Student Resident Association), as well as minutes of its executive committee, board of directors, and board of trustees, and of the Inter-Cooperative Council; committee aned financial reports; and constitutions, by-laws, codes, rosters, and programs of the organization. Also, correspondence, mainly of lodge advisor Edward A. Ott, concerning election of officers, functions of the lodge, name changes, and other business; other correspondents include Robert B. Gervan, Hugh A. Moran, and Robert E. Treman. Also the files of William Ballagh which include correspondence and publications documenting the history of the group during the 1930s and 1940s. Also digital scans of the Ballagh material.

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: Cayuga Student Residence Association. Cornell University,

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 1-5 restricted to the permission of the President of Cayuga Lodge. Files of William Ballagh are not restricted.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Cayuga Lodge papers, #37-4-824. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: See also the thesis Building history : how the Cornell family's brick carriage house became Cayuga Lodge by Rebecca Baker.

did.unittitle: Records awaiting further description
William Ballagh Cornell Class of 1937 files

scopecontent.p: These files and inventory were compiled March 28, 2017 by Tom Ballagh, ’67, BS, Agr., Resident Member 1963-66, Associate Member 1966-67, from materials provided by his father, Bill Ballagh, ’37, BS, Agr., Resident Member 1934-37, President of Permanent Membership Committee, 1937-44; Dick Kline,’64, BS, Agr., ’65, MBA, Resident Member 1960-64, son of Dick Kline, ’39, BS, Agr., Resident Member 1935-39; and others.

did.unittitle: Cayuga Student Residence Assn. Permanent Membership News Bulletin Vol V No. 2
Personal letter from Bruce Cormack from “Somewhere in Bataan”

scopecontent.p: (Note: Bruce was later to survive the Bataan Death March and return home). Letter copied on the back is from Bruce’s mother to Amy Ballagh (sister of Bill). Original of the letter was sent to Bruce in 1987 (see correspondence from Bruce Cormack to Tom Ballagh, ’67 in Folder 16 section of the index

scopecontent.p: The stress of the War is evident in Dr. Ott’s reporting. He expressed his appreciation for the condolences received for the death of his sister, Mrs. Hinshaw on January 2, 1944.

did.unittitle: Cayuga Student Residence Assn. Permanent Membership News Bulletin Vol. VI No. 2
Form letter by Dr. Ott entitled “NEVER STOP COOPERATING” encouraging recruitment of residents and benefits of cooperative living over fraternities
Minutes of Cayuga Student Residence Assn. Board of Trustees. Dr. Ott submitted his resignation as Resident Advisor which was accepted with regret and many expressions of appreciation
Circular letter from Dr. Ott on his declining eyesight and installation of the “Talking Book Machine” in his library. He requested letters from friends

From letter from Hugh Moran to Fellow Members of Cayuga Student Residence Assn. announcing the retirement of Dr. Ott and appointment of officers of the Board of Trustees under the war-time powers of the Association Constitution amendment dated 12/22/1942, letter dated 6/22/1945
Form letter from Hugh Moran to “All the Old Crowd at Cayuga Lodge”

scopecontent.p: Announces Dr. Ott had moved from the Lodge and in with his daughter and two grandchildren on their farm. Mr. Moran was very hopeful for a prosperous future for the Lodge. He attached Lee Whitford’s August 8, 1945 extensive report to the Permanent Members.

scopecontent.p: sent to Lee Whitford and returned later by his widow, Jean Whitford following his death

scopecontent.p: (A quote from his letter: “My last recollection of Dr. Ott came in the 1950’s. I knew that he was very ill, and while presiding at a meeting of the Board of Directors at the Lodge, we received word that he had passed away. It was a sad moment for all of us.”)
